The GS-7 Biological Science Technician will serve as a program leader for natural resource management projects related to habitat restoration, survey, and invasive plant management. Duties will include identifying plants; surveying for target invasive species; collecting field data and recording the data into established or new databases; collecting GPS and GIS data; leading crews in treatments including chainsaw and herbicide safety. Successful applicants will lead teams that may include NPS seasonal, interns, volunteers, and other agency staff. They may be asked to occasionally lead larger groups of volunteers in projects. Herbicide use and some overnight backcountry camping can be expected. Global positioning systems, aerial photographs, topographic maps, and/or compass may be used in navigation. Duties in the winter season will include work planning and partnership building with external partners along with the lead plant biologist. This position will serve as a technical expert on safety related to equipment, chemicals, and field operations.

Physical Demands: The work is partially sedentary with prolonged standing, walking, and bending often required. Heavy items (e.g., equipment and packs up to 50 pounds) must be lifted and carried on a routine basis. Hiking 8 miles daily. Maintaining license and applying herbicide and pesticide.

Working Conditions: The work is performed in an office, laboratory, and in the field. Field work includes exposure to extreme weather conditions and terrain, pesticides, poisonous plants, biting insects, and wild animals. Laboratory work may involve exposure to hazardous chemicals.
